item.title: Destiny 2: Heresy Will Be Missing Some Voice Content Because Of The Ongoing Actors Strike
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/destiny-2-heresy-will-be-missing-some-voice-content-because-of-the-ongoing-actors-strike/1100-6529182/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Last summer, SAG-AFTRA called for a voice actors strike against video game publishers over numerous issues including AI protections. Although the union has reached deals with a handful of publishers, the strike is still ongoing. Now, Bungie has confirmed that the upcoming Destiny 2: Heresy expansion will include scenes that are missing spoken dialogue because a deal with the actors has yet to be reached.

In an update on Bungie's official site, the developer noted that "certain voice lines" were not recorded because of the actors strike. In those scenes, Destiny 2 will enable subtitles by default in order to carry the narrative forward despite the missing audio. The update also notes that any Heresy activities that are missing voice overs will feature an on-screen warning before starting. However, the update doesn't address whether those lines will be recorded when the strike ends.

Over on Bluesky, a voice actor going by Orchid shared their response to the news by reiterating the actors' desire to "get a fair deal" that addresses their AI concerns.

For everyone complaining: we‚Äôre still on strike. We would like to work, but until we get a fair deal, our concerns regarding AI addressed, etc, we will not. I‚Äôm sorry this affects your games, but it also affects our ability to pay our rent and grocery bills.

[image or embed]

‚Äî Orchidüîªüê∫üåø (@heyitsorchid.bsky.social) January 30, 2025 at 1:37 PM

Destiny 2 isn't the only game being affected by the strikes. Hideo Kojima has disclosed that his upcoming titles--including OD and Physint--are also unable to record the dialogue they need from their performers.

As for Destiny 2, the Heresy expansion will begin on February 4 with a return to the Dreadnaught. Heresy will also feature a new dungeon, Sundered Doctrine, as well as a collaboration with Star Wars that introduce gear, armor ornaments, accessories, emotes, and finishers that are inspired by some of the Empire's fiercest warriors including the Death Troopers and the Imperial Guards.

item.title: Killing Floor 3 Has Three Editions - Physical Preorders Available Now
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/killing-floor-3-has-three-editions-physical-preorders-available-now/1100-6529177/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Prepare for more Zeds, as Killing Floor 3 is officially launching on March 25 for PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X. Fans of the cooperative FPS franchise can sign up for the chance to participate in the February 20-24 closed beta. If you're looking forward to Killing Floor 3, you can secure your preorder now. Three different versions are up for grabs, including a budget-friendly physical edition with a few in-game bonuses.

Killing Floor 3 Preorder Bonuses

All Killing Floor 3 preorders come with with the Flatline Tactical Bundle or the Clamefield Patrol Specialist Skins Pack. The Flatline Tactical Bundle includes the following in-game goodies:

  • Flatliner weapon skin
  • Fear the Reaper trinket
  • Special Action Force player card

It's not entirely clear which retailers have the Flatline Pack and which have the Clamefield Pack, but all preorders include one of them.

Killing Floor 3 Standard Edition

$40

Killing Floor 3 is only $40 instead of the usual $60-$70 for most big new releases. This gets you the base game, any eligible preorder bonuses, and either the Clamefield Patrol Specialist Skins Pack or the Flatline Tactical Bundle (depending on the retailer). Digital editions are available on the PS Store and Xbox Store. For PC, you‚Äôll find it on Steam. You can wishlist the Steam version on Fanatical, which is potentially notable because the retailer--a GameSpot sister site--often has preorder discounts and launch deals.

Killing Floor 3 Deluxe Edition

$60

Step up to the Deluxe Edition to get the base game, all eligible preorder bonuses, and the following:

  • Shadow Agent Specialist & Weapon Skin Sets
  • Launch Nightfall Supply Pass
  • 1,000 Creds

Killing Floor 3 Elite Nightfall Edition

$80

It‚Äôs a bit pricey, but it‚Äôs loaded with some great bonus content. Along with everything from the Deluxe Edition, the Elite Nightfall Edition comes with the following:

  • Year One Premium Nightfall Supply Pass Access (4 Passes)
  • 3,000 Creds

Want to check out the closed beta? Head over to the official Killing Floor 3 website to sign up for the waitlist.

Killing Floor 3 is making some big upgrades over its predecessor, including a revamped gore system that promises to be more bloody and brutal than ever before. Dubbed the MEAT System, enemies are designed with more dismemberment points and persistent blood--meaning maps should look absolutely gruesome at the end of each wave. You'll also get to explore new environments with interactive components, like turrets and fans, to create deadly traps for the Zeds.

Games are designed for up to six players, and you'll have plenty of weapons at your disposal to help tame the hordes. This includes flamethrowers, shotguns, katanas, and hundreds of customizable mods and gadgets. You'll need them too, as the AI has been reworked to be more punishing, so prepare to fight for your life on March 25.

item.title: Four Years After Microsoft Acquisition, Esports Site Start.gg Goes Independent With Some Changes
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/four-years-after-microsoft-acquisition-esports-site-start-gg-goes-independent-with-some-changes/1100-6529180/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Just over four years ago, Microsoft purchased the esports tournament organizing platform Start.gg, which was then known as Smash.gg before its rebranding. Now, Start.gg has announced that Microsoft no longer owns the site and stated that it will "be returning to its roots as an independent company supporting grassroots and professional esports communities."

Chris Ogle--the co-founder of Smash.gg--shared the news on Medium and thanked Microsoft and Xbox for their support. He also noted that the site will continue with members from the original Smash.gg team alongside "grassroots tournament organizers, and engineers who are passionate about improving the platform for the communities we support."

One of the biggest changes going forward is that starting on February 14, Start.gg will be charging a registration fee to support the expenses of running the site. In addition to making that change for the sustainability of the business, Start.gg will be upgrading its user interface and tournament support.

"Since our inception back in 2015, our goal has always been to foster esports communities around the games people love to play," wrote Ogle. "This goal remains at the heart of everything we do, and we look forward to continuing our journey with you."

Despite some downward trends in the gaming industry, esports remain popular. Last year's Evo 2024 was officially the largest esports competition ever. Evo 2025 will look to maintain that momentum when it returns to Las Vegas between August 1-3.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
